title: Case Study: Resisting Price Increases
scenario: You are the procurement manager at a mid-sized manufacturer. A key supplier emails announcing a 10% price increase, citing 'inflationary pressures and rising energy costs'. Your CFO wants continuity but expects you to resist unjustified costs.
learning_objectives: Recognize supplier tactics in price increases
Apply data-driven verification and negotiation steps
Practice value-based and risk-aware procurement skills

analysis: Always request a cost breakdown (cost tree).
Cross-check supplier claims with trusted indices.
costs: Challenge components that have not increased.
Avoid debating a flat percentage; focus on itemized data.
market: Insist on symmetry: reductions when inputs fall.
negotiation: Trade price for terms, lead time, or service improvements.
Reject firmly but remain respectful to the person.
strategy: Adapt tactics to supplier category (strategic vs leverage).
Benchmark and maintain at least one viable alternative.
improvement: Document negotiation outcomes and lessons learned.
Ensure tactics used comply with ethics and policy.

questions.stem: What is the best first step when you receive the supplier’s 10% increase request?
options: Accept the increase to ensure continuity
Escalate directly to CFO without reply
questions.explain: Step 1 is to reject the increase firmly but professionally.
hints: Signal you are not a price taker.

questions.stem: Why do some suppliers announce vague across-the-board increases?
options: To test which customers are price takers
Because all input costs always rise together
questions.explain: Suppliers often 'test the waters' to see who resists.

questions.stem: Which TWO actions are essential when verifying a supplier’s claim?
Energy is 12% of COGS. The index rises 20%. What is the legitimate pass-through?
Why break down a supplier’s cost structure instead of debating a flat %?
options: It reveals which inputs truly drive increases
It makes the supplier feel supported
questions.explain: Breaking down reveals what is real vs inflated.

questions.stem: Which TWO practices enforce fairness when commodity costs drop?
options: Wait for supplier to propose reductions

questions.stem: Supplier refuses to reduce prices when indices fall. What should you do?
options: Initiate the reduction discussion using data
questions.explain: Be proactive: present data and request reduction.

questions.stem: If you cannot block an increase fully, which TWO tactics manage impact?
options: Accept full increase and pass on to customers
questions.explain: Deferrals and phasing mitigate short-term impact.

options: Accept +3% if supplier cuts lead time by 20%
questions.explain: Trade price for service improvements = value-based.

questions.stem: When is switching suppliers the right strategy?
options: After exhausting collaboration and when alternatives exist
At the first sign of any increase
Whenever another supplier offers any discount
questions.explain: Switching is a last resort, only with alternatives.
